classmethod identity()¶

Returns: multiplicative_identity (QubitOperator):

A QubitOperator id with the property that id * x = x * id = x for all operators x of the same class.
Note:
This identity operator are quite useful to calculate the power of the same tpye operator
is_two_body_number_conserving(check_spin_symmetry=False)¶

Check whether has the correct form to make a molecular Requires every sub term is particle number conserving, that is the number of raising and lowering operators are equal.Also need to check the parity(spin) conservation(Z2 symmetry). Note the molecular term should compose of constant term, h_pq adagger_p*a_q, h_pqrs adagger_p*dagger_q*a_r*a_s,

Args:
check_spin_symmetry(bool): whether to check spin conservation.
Returns:
return True if it is two_body_number_conserving.

normal_ordered()¶
parse_long_string(long_string, coefficient=1.0)¶

parse a long string representation.

e.g. For FermionOperator:
‘1.5j [2^ 1] + 1.4 [4^ 0]’
e.g. For QubitOperator:
‘1.5j [X1 Y2] + 1.4 [Z1 Y2]’
parse_sequence(terms)¶

Parse a term given as a sequency type (i.e. list, tuple, etc.).

e.g. For QubitOperator:
[(2, ‘X’), (0, ‘Y’), (3,’Z’)] -> ((0, ‘Y’),(2, ‘X’), (3,’Z’))

Note for the single term case [1,’X’]->((1,’X’),)

parse_string(terms_string)¶

Parse a term given as a string type

e.g. For QubitOperator:
‘X2 Y0 Z3’ -> ((0, ‘Y’),(2, ‘X’), (3,’Z’))
Returns:
return A tuple list, such as ((0, ‘Y’),(2, ‘X’), (3,’Z’))
Raises:
‘XX2’ or ‘1.5 X2’ is not the proper format and could raise TypeError.
parse_term(term)¶

classmethod zero()¶
Returns:
additive_identity (QubitOperator):
A qubit type operator o with the property that o + x = x + o = x for all operators x from the same class.
Note:
This zero operator is quite useful to deal with sum of partial operators into a complicated one
hiqfermion.ops.fermion_operator.normal_ordered(fermion_operator)¶

Calculate and return the normal order of the FermionOperator. By convention, normal ordering implies terms are ordered from highest mode index (on left) to lowest (on right). Also, creation operators come first then follows the annihilation operator. e.g 3 4^ -> - 4^ 3

hiqfermion.ops.fermion_operator.normal_ordered_term(term, coefficient)¶

hiqfermion.ops.interaction_operator module¶

class hiqfermion.ops.interaction_operator.InteractionOperator(constant, one_body_tensor, two_body_tensor)¶

Bases: hiqfermion.ops.polynomial_tensor.PolynomialTensor

Class to store ‘interaction opeartors’ which are used to configure a ferinonic molecular Hamiltonian. The Hamiltonian including one-body and two-body terms which conserve spin and parity. In this module, The stored coefficient could be represented the molecualr Hamiltonians througth the FermionOperator class. Note that the operators stored in this class has the form: constant + sum_{p, q} h_[p, q] a^dagger_p a_q +

sum_{p, q, r, s} h_[p, q, r, s] a^dagger_p a^dagger_q a_r a_s.
Attributes:
constant: A constant term in the operator given as a
float. For instance, the nuclear repulsion energy.
one_body_tensor: The coefficients of the one-body terms (h[p, q]).
This is an n_qubits x n_qubits numpy array of floats. By default we store the numpy array with keys: a^dagger_p a_q (1,0).
two_body_tensor: The coefficients of the two-body terms
(h[p, q, r, s]). This is an n_qubits x n_qubits x n_qubits x n_qubits numpy array of floats.By default we store the numpy array with keys: a^dagger_p a^dagger_q a_r a_s (1, 1, 0, 0).
unique_iter(complex_valued=False)¶

Iterate all terms that are not in the same symmetry group. Four point symmetry:

  1. pq = qp.
  2. pqrs = srqp = qpsr = rspq.
Eight point symmetry(when complex_valued is False):
  1. pq = qp.
  2. pqrs = rqps = psrq = srqp = qpsr = rspq = spqr = qrsp.
Args:
complex_valued (bool):
Whether the operator has complex coefficients.
Yields:
tuple[int]
exception hiqfermion.ops.interaction_operator.InteractionOperatorError¶

Bases: Exception

hiqfermion.ops.interaction_rdm module¶

This is the class to store the reduced density matrix that used to calculate the expectation value of Hamiltonian

class hiqfermion.ops.interaction_rdm.InteractionRDM(one_body_tensor, two_body_tensor)¶

Bases: hiqfermion.ops.polynomial_tensor.PolynomialTensor

class that stores the one-body and two-body reduced density matrix.

Args:
one_body_tensor: the expectation value <a^dagger_p a_q> of one-body term two_body_tensor: the expectation value <a^dagger_p a^dagger_q a_r a_s> of two-body term
expectation(operator)¶

Return expectation value of an InteractionRDM with an InteractionOperator.

Args:
operator: A InteractionOperator.
Returns:
float: Expectation value
Raises:
InteractionRDMError: Invalid operator provided.

hiqfermion.ops.polynomial_tensor module¶

class hiqfermion.ops.polynomial_tensor.PolynomialTensor(n_body_tensors=None)¶

Bases: object

Class to store the coefficient of the fermionic ladder opeators in a tensor form For instance, in a molecular Hamiltonian (degree 4 polynomial) which conserves particle number, there are only three kinds of terms, namely constant term, single excitation a^dagger_p a_q and double excitation terms a^dagger_p a^dagger_q a_r a_s, and their corresponding coefficients can be stored in an scalar, n_qubits x n_qubits matrix and n_qubits x n_qubits x n_qubits x n_qubits matrix. Note that each tensor must have an even number of dimensions due to the parity conservation. Much of the functionality of this class is similar to that of FermionOperator

Args:

n_qubits(int): The number of the sites that tensor operator acts. n_body_tensors(dict): A dictionary storing the tensors describing

n-body interactions. The keys are tuples that indicate the type of tensor. For instance, n_body_tensors[()] would return a constant, while a n_body_tensors[(1, 0)] would be an (n_qubits x n_qubits) numpy array, and n_body_tensors[(1,1,0,1)] would return a (n_qubits x n_qubits x n_qubits x n_qubits) numpy array and those constant and array represent the coefficients of terms of the form identity, a^dagger_p a_q, a^dagger_p a^dagger_1 a_r a_s, respectively. Note here ‘1’ represent a^dagger, while ‘0’ represent a.
constant¶

get the value of the identity term

one_body_tensor¶

get the one-body term

rotate_basis(u)¶
two_body_tensor¶

get the two body term

exception hiqfermion.ops.polynomial_tensor.PolynomialTensorError¶

Bases: Exception

hiqfermion.ops.qubit_operator module¶

class hiqfermion.ops.qubit_operator.QubitOperator(term=None, coefficient=1.0)¶

Bases: object

A sum of terms acting on qubits, e.g., 0.5 * ‘X1 X5’ + 0.3 * ‘Z1 Z2’. A term is an operator acting on n qubits and can be represented as: coefficient * local_operator[0] x … x local_operator[n-1] where x is the tensor product. A local operator is a Pauli operator (‘I’, ‘X’, ‘Y’, or ‘Z’) which acts on one qubit. In math notation a term is, for example, 0.5 * ‘X1 X5’, which means that a Pauli X operator acts on qubit 1 and 5, while the identity operator acts on all the rest qubits.

Note for a QubitOperator to be a Hamiltonian which is a hermitian operator, the coefficients of all terms must be real.

hamiltonian = 0.5 * QubitOperator('X0 X5') + 0.3 * QubitOperator('Z0')
QubitOperator has the following attributes set as follows::
operators = (‘X’, ‘Y’, ‘Z’) different_indices_commute = True
Example:
ham = ((QubitOperator('X0 Y3', 0.5)
        + 0.6 * QubitOperator('X0 Y3')))
# Equivalently
ham2 = QubitOperator('X0 Y3', 0.5)
ham2 += 0.6 * QubitOperator('X0 Y3')

simplify(terms, coefficient=1.0)¶

Simplify the list by using the commuation and anti-commutation relationship. Args:

The input terms_lst could be a sorted list or unsorted list e.g. [(3, ‘Z’),(2, ‘X’), (3,’Z’)] -> [(2,’X’)] Also, it could accept input with tuples ((3, ‘Z’),(2, ‘X’), (3,’Z’)) ->[(2,’X’)]

hiqfermion.ops.time_evolution module¶

hiqfermion.ops.time_evolution.TimeEvolution(time, hamiltonian)¶

Converts the Hamiltonian to an instance of the ProjectQ QubitOperator and then returns an instance of the ProjectQ TimeEvolution gate. This gate is the unitary time evolution propagator: exp(-i * H * t), where H is the Hamiltonian of the system and t is the time. Note that -i factor is stored implicitly.

Example:
wavefunction = eng.allocate_qureg(5) hamiltonian = 0.5 * QubitOperator(“X0 Z1”) # Apply exp(-i * H * t) to the wavefunction: TimeEvolution(time=1.0, hamiltonian=hamiltonian) | wavefunction
Args:
time(float, int): time t hamiltonian(QubitOperator): hamiltonaian H
Returns:
Instance of ProjectQ TimeEvolution gate.
Raises:
TypeError: If time is not a numeric type and hamiltonian is not a
QubitOperator.
Note:
The time duration for the evolution is default to be 1.0
